body:
@korneil It seems to be an import error. Can you confirm that this error occur only when you have a script file containing nothing but

```
import mxnet
```

and yet you can run the built-in examples without problem (e.g. mnist/mlp.py)?
@pluskid Get it. Thanks !

Some code from `FeedForward` should definitely be refactored and put into super class once we have another model type. I vote for not having a separate trainer. Because different models will have different training logics. For example, RNN models will need to maintain states transition, gradient cut-off over time.

Let us move this issue to https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow

We can update the CropExp to support RValue evaluation, reference slice expression https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/blob/master/mshadow/extension/slice.h So you can use it at right side of assignment
Let us know if you are interested in contributing this.
@tqchen , yes ,i'll try this.
great suggestions - I uninstalled the experimental version of GCC and used clang instead. It works! Thank you both very much

I use `git rebase -i HEAD~x`(I don't know which x is right, so I tried 16). Then I found my first commit "add option to plot network in other shapes", deleted those commits before it and changed my commits after it to `squash`. But then I got error: `error: could not apply e83622c... overload other operators`. What should I do correctly?

hack1nt0 from sina weibo http://www.weibo.com/1762781217 proposed and tested his own clang-omp and clang-omp++ solution for using OpenMP with BLAS on Mac. If CPU only, openmp is not really necessary because BLAS can take care of multi-thread and fully utilize CPUs, but with multiple GPU, it still make some sense.

![](http://ww1.sinaimg.cn/large/6911e821jw1ey9rzfiebij20ku03cmzd.jpg)

cc @antinucleon @pluskid 

The API is backward compatible, with a new API ExecutorBindX, that allows additional mapping, we can open an issue discussing model parallel interface.
this is enabled by #690
Though the higher level interface might still need some discussion

There is conflicts with the master, that you might need to solve. Sorry for all the troubles

http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#how-to-resolve-conflict-with-master
Maybe easier way might be keep what you have and start from a cleaner fork, if the rebase does not work out
@tqchen How to start from a clean fork. Do I need to delete my former fork?
That is one way I can think of. Normally I use the rebase workflow to pull changes from upstream instead of PR back, which is easier to squash changes
@tqchen  Thanks. I create a new pull request from a clean fork just now.

I thought I fixed it...

The latest version of the binary are linked with static runtime library.
Let me try it on a clean machine.

updated PR #669, from issue #663

Ilya Loshchilov, Frank Hutter. Online Batch Selection for Faster Training of Neural Networks. ICLR 2016. http://arxiv.org/abs/1511.06343
"Our experimental results on the MNIST dataset suggest that selecting batches speeds up both AdaDelta and Adam by a factor of about 5."

Code is available at https://sites.google.com/site/batchsel/.

hi, guys. 
The travis.ci says the build `errored` not build `failed`. I have found a few pr get a build error when build cpp_test and build process stoped at "the fox says 42....". 
How to deal with this?
thanks for your help. I have changed my OS to ubuntu. So I don't know whether your suggestion is a good solution. Anyway, thanks.
@piiswrong
It's here I think https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/train_mnist.py
I prefer 3 or 4 like this http://scikit-learn.org/stable/auto_examples/
@mli

I implemented a volumetric convolution layer that uses only cudnn for the sake of brevity. Bc the input is now 5D instead 4, I will have to adopt activation layer as well for 5D. Do you recomment to create a new layer like "VolumetricActivation", or would you rather prefer to change the code of the current activation operator?

Hi - Our work [3][4] differs from [1] in class weighting as you pointed out. Another major difference is the much more efficient parametrisation in SegNet [4], which is an order of magnitude faster to run, and can be trained end to end in one step. I believe DeConvNet [1] uses stage wise training and multiple region proposals in inference time.

We found class weighting to be very important for scene understanding tasks. If you are more interested in datasets such as [SUN](http://mi.eng.cam.ac.uk/research/projects/VideoRec/CamVid/) or [CamVid](http://rgbd.cs.princeton.edu/) then I'd recommend implementing it. Cheers.

Thanks,
If you are working on volumetric convolution, consider open a work in progress PR to get feed backs.

1) in_grad is grad for input, or bottom_grad. out_grad is from top. It's uninitialized if need_top_grad=False, i.e. for loss layer. Otherwise it comes from layers above.
2) It's in mshadow/cuda/tensor-gpu.cuh
@korneil I think activation should work for any input dimension, like the non-cudnn version already does.
when things fail in the engine, you can try using NAIVE_ENGINE, and backtrace will give you the call hierarchy.

Hi @lukemetz,
Thanks for the contribution. This is definitely a useful feature. Just two comments:
1) I would recommend remove loss_op and sum_all_op and implement those functions in python with imperative operations, e.g. x.asnumpy().sum(). And add a python class GradientChecker.
2) Your code doesn't seem to build under linux.

Maybe it's something obvious that I miss.
Any idea?

try 
`std::vector <Tensor<xpu, 5> > data(size_);`
You need a space there.
Oh, great thanks, works!

Your welcome.
BTW, I think it's better to merge activation, concat and pooling into the old ops. These should be shape agnostic. Especially activation.

Thanks,

1) Will do. What is the logic for which ops to drop down to cpp? 
Also, Should GradientChecker be in the test module or the mxnet module? 
2) ya. sorry about that. One to many late night changes...

I think the logic is:
a) generic ops useful for many tasks, or
b) performance critical.
Gradient checker doesn't really justify b) since you only run it once for each op.
loss_op doesn't justify a) either. Sum_all op however, does fit in a). But you actually can implement it with much less code by using src/ndarray/ndarray_function.
Some thing like this:
MXNET_REGISTER_TBLOB_FUN(square, XPU)
.set_function(XPU::kDevMask, UnaryForward_<XPU, op::mshadow_op::square>, true)
.set_gradient(XPU::kDevMask, UnaryBackwardUseIn_<XPU, op::mshadow_op::square_grad>, true)
.describe("Take square of the src");

Sumall should go to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/ndarray/unary_function-inl.h 

Reference the implementation of norm. I am a bit sorry for the confusion in code locations, in a sense that they should be moved to op and more highlighted, this file is the place to implement the Unary operator easily and being exposed to both NDArray and symbolic api.

Thanks for the contribution!
+1 for moving concat and activations into old generic operators. The support for activation should already been generic and accept 5D tensors, so no re-implementation is needed
@mli can you help review this?

I will, thanks!

Is there an easy way to dump an output of a symbolic variable in python, or get it as a numpy array? I wonder if I can easily double check e.g. the pooling if it works well. If no, I just print it in C.

x = mx.sym.XXX
X = mx.nd.ndarray()
exe = x.bind(args{'x': X})
exe.forward()
X.asnumpy()

@piiswrong please remove the C++ type from the C API as it can bring in problems when introducing a C++ type to a C FFI, please use NDArrayHandle instead
Closing for now

Thanks all for your reply.

I am working on predicting pixel-wise labels, not necessarily image segmentation. The distributions of labels are highly unbalanced. Experimental results based on MatConvNet indicate that weighted loss is quite helpful. MatConvNet, however, is very slow. So I am considering to switch using other packages.
probably due to 1) gpu(0) is not available on your laptop, or 2) you still bind the model into gpu(1) on your laptop
updated https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example

no,no.
if I load the parameters trained on gpu(0) of server, it will have no any problem. My laptop only have one gpu.
I find something useful https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/predict-with-pretrained-model.ipynbin.
Cool, SegNet can do that and it is built on Caffe which is pretty fast - you might find [this tutorial](http://mi.eng.cam.ac.uk/projects/segnet/tutorial.html) helpful.

remove -msse3 in file `mshadow/make/mshadow.mk` and `mshadow/test/Makefile`.
set `#define MSHADOW_USE_SSE 0` in file `mshadow/mshadow/base.h`.
but still have error:

```
In file included from src/operator/lrn.cc:10:0:
src/operator/./cudnn_lrn-inl.h:130:3: error: â€˜cudnnLRNDescriptor_tâ€™ does not name a type
   cudnnLRNDescriptor_t lrn_desc_;
```

there is cuda-6.5 in the TK1 device.

Once https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/640 is completed, most of the published image segmentation models that are based on FCN can be replicated without much difficulty in MXNet.

Maybe most pre-trained models can even be imported directly.

I had to edit `config.mk` to get it to compile:

```
export CC = clang-omp
export CXX = clang-omp++
USE_OPENMP = 1
```

I also had to install `clang-omp` via brew:

``` bash
brew install clang-omp
brew install pkg-config
```

The directions I followed are here: https://medium.com/@lelayf/installing-mxnet-for-r-on-yosemite-291470055980#.4tn8uqst6

It seems that you have to update your mshadow code. The newest mshadow added function "take" and "take_grad"
In git, type commands below
"
git submodule init
git submodule update
"
Hope this will help

![download](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1258974/11377043/3d0ea44a-92a1-11e5-9910-c5b3099f82e3.png)

I have done most parts, but seems there are minor issues need to be fixed.
As you can see this is due to CUDNN turned on, compile without CuDNN should work

I think this is due to the `-fstack-protector-strong` flag you are using.

Can you remove it and try again?
Actually I have compiled mxnet on TK1 without CuDNN weeks ago.
@hjk41 Could you take a look? -lnvrtc and -lcuda are used by MXNET's LDFLAG, not mshadow's. Is this going to be a problem?

where is your opencv installed? if not in the standard directory you'll need to add it to CFLAGS and LDFLAGS.

Also, I'm not sure about this is relevant by opencv 2.0 seems too old
I think we want to simply forbid taking gradient of sign, as it is not smooth and usually it won't behaves as it supposed to be.  Consider not registering sign grad

I'll do it tomorrow. I also think it's the cause. 

I'm using all the default options btw, I'll see if it's an Mxnet option, Rcpp option or R option and report back

Thanks
superb, what is the speed? i can start drafting a blog of advertising it
@piiswrong  it only name.

@zachmayer yes, if use clang-omp, these changes are needed, my test also confirms this. OpenMP is primarily for multi-GPU for fast data loading (from my understanding) while BLAS can take care of multi-thread CPU. Since most of Macs don't have multi-CUDA-GPU cards, clang-omp may not be necessary. Is it correct?
It should be from R. Maybe you can check the file `/etc/R/Makeconf`
Someone made a demo for tensorflow too: https://github.com/woodrush/neural-art-tf

Saw the tensor flow demo too. They use the exact same caffe model as in the Lua version. Seems like the number of iteration is not large enough for understanding the style. It should be around 800-100 from the Lua version, which is the reason why take so long (2 min with Titan X). If mxnet can simply this iteration for searching for optimal parameters, mxnet can save much time. The lua version mentioned their `-optimizer` parameter in the README https://github.com/jcjohnson/neural-style

I'm excited to see the results!  Also, there's already another one:
https://github.com/anishathalye/neural-style

tensor flow has some great marketing...

![out16](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/421857/11384641/75843e5a-92df-11e5-9960-102346a3e95b.jpg)

we can almost reproduce the results, thanks to @antinucleon 

but the major problem is the speed. it needs thousands of iterations which takes minutes on a decent gpu cards..
@mli Is there code somewhere to reproduce the results I could try out myself?
i just see this, i'll do it this week~
cudnn is fast, will it affect the performance by disable it?

I met some issues when I tried to use cudnn with Theano on TK1, so I disabled it this time.

I can have some test in the weekends.
As a side note, I was originally having trouble installing openCV so I went through these steps:
http://blogs.wcode.org/2014/10/howto-install-build-and-use-opencv-macosx-10-10/
Still getting an error. [Here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/43437/Output.txt) is the full output when I follow instructions posted by @zachmayer and run make -j4

I got this error when trying to access a buffer from python that supposedly has data copied from gpu:

``` python
    dev = mx.gpu()

    sym = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=data, name="x")
    data = mx.nd.ones([1, 1, 5, 5, 5])
    exe = sym.bind(dev, {'data': data})
    exe.forward()

    for v in exe.outputs:
        d = mx.nd.empty(v.shape, ctx=mx.cpu())
        v.copyto(d)
        print d.asnumpy()
```

The code fails at print d.asnumpy(). Output:

```
[03:02:23] ./dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:208: [03:02:23] ./mshadow/mshadow/./tensor_blob.h:476: Check failed: Device::kDevMask == dev_mask_ && DataType<DType>::kFlag == type_flag_ TBlob.get: device type do not match specified type
[03:02:23] ./dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:208: [03:02:23] src/engine/./threaded_engine.h:295: [03:02:23] ./mshadow/mshadow/./tensor_blob.h:476: Check failed: Device::kDevMask == dev_mask_ && DataType<DType>::kFlag == type_flag_ TBlob.get: device type do not match specified type
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'dmlc::Error'
  what():  [03:02:23] src/engine/./threaded_engine.h:295: [03:02:23] ./mshadow/mshadow/./tensor_blob.h:476: Check failed: Device::kDevMask == dev_mask_ && DataType<DType>::kFlag == type_flag_ TBlob.get: device type do not match specified type
```

Deleted all of the cpp code infavor of a NumpyOp. This will work perfectly fine for tests but will not scale as talked about. I figured this was way less code as this SumAll would need to be converted to a "loss" op anyway.

Sorry for all the questions, but one more thing: What exactly do you mean by a GradientChecker class? The function itself is stateless so what would go in this class? Utilities to check relative / absolute error like in [theano](https://github.com/Theano/Theano/blob/master/theano/gradient.py#L1353)?
@mwegman4 have you tried `brew install opencv` as in the instruction? If opencv is built by source, it may not find all correct PATH variables.

This looks like you allocated a gpu/cpu array and used it for cpu/gpu

``` python
dev = mx.gpu()
data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
sym = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=data, name="x")
data = mx.nd.ones([1, 1, 5, 5, 5])
exe = sym.bind(dev, {'data': data})
exe.forward()

for v in exe.outputs:
    d = mx.nd.empty(v.shape, ctx=mx.cpu())
    v.copyto(d)
    print d.asnumpy()
```

This code works fine for me

Looks like it's stuck on c++ side.
Doesn't happen on my machine. Have you tried other examples? Is it the same for them?

could you try example/image-classification/train_cifar10.py?
The examples under notebooks might be out dated.

Thanks piiswrong!

I can run example/cifar10/cifar10 without any problem. In the new version example/image-classification/train_cifar10.py is not that much different. 

The problem is when I use the notebook example, where there is extra code for testing. During testing, "for _, label in test_dataiter:" seems to be unpacking from an iterator (defined as MXDataIter). 

Anyway, the sad story is that I have to use mxnet on windows for now and I am using the pre-build version from https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases as recommended. Maybe the pre-build version is obsolete. If there is really no other way around, say, the behavior of the iterator class totally changed in the new version, I will bother to compile the latest version from scratch. But it will very be helpful to me if you can let me know how you guys get it passed at the first time you ran the notebooks. Thanks a lot.

@mwegman4 In your log,

```
ld: warning: object file (/usr/local/lib/libopencv_imgcodecs.a(loadsave.cpp.o)) was built for newer OSX version (10.11) than being linked (10.10)
```

It indicates you have more than one version of opencv installed on your system. My advice is to remove them and reinstall opencv through `brew`

I need this when building R package with binary file last Sunday.

It is a definitely clean Windows server on AWS. But this VS runtime should have been installed on most Windows machines, since many applications need it.
Does your GPU work fine with other GPU test tools? How many GPUs in the machine?

thanks for reporting this issue. I will fix it in the next release
